headline.main: People With Individual Health Plans Would Save Out-of-Pocket Under Reform, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Older and lower-income Americans who buy their own health insurance would save under health reform, a study finds.
docs.snippet: Older and lower-income Americans who buy their own health insurance would save under health reform, a study finds.

docs.abstract: WellPoint has agreed to buy 1-800 Contacts, the contact lens retailer, from the private equity firm Fenway Partners, in a bid to bolster its relationships with consumers.
docs.snippet: WellPoint has agreed to buy 1-800 Contacts, the contact lens retailer, from the private equity firm Fenway Partners, in a bid to bolster its relationships with consumers.

docs.abstract: Spending cuts favored by Republicans would not simply reduce commitments not covered by projected revenues, but would shift them to individuals and families.

docs.lead_paragraph: State Senator Thomas K. Duane, 57, said he had simply tired of ricocheting between New York City and Albany, as he has for nearly 14 years.

headline.seo: State Senator Thomas Duane, a Gay Rights Advocate, to Retire
headline.main: Champion of Gay Rights to Leave New York State Senate
headline.print_headline: Longtime Gay Rights Champion to Retire From the State Senate

docs.abstract: New York State Senator Thomas K Duane announces his decision to retire after nearly 14 years; Duane made his mark as the first openly gay member of the State Senate and was a pivotal figure during the state's recent same-sex marriage battle.
docs.snippet: State Senator Thomas K. Duane, 57, said he had simply tired of ricocheting between New York City and Albany, as he has for nearly 14 years.

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Narcotic painkillers, which can mask rather than treat pain, can increase disability payouts and expenses by delaying an employee’s return to work.

headline.seo: Painkillers Add Costs and Delays to Workplace Injuries
headline.main: Pain Pills Add Cost and Delays to Job Injuries
headline.print_headline: Pain Pills Add Cost and Delays To Job Injuries

docs.abstract: Workplace insurers are reckoning with a growing number of payouts to workers with routine injuries who have been treated with strong painkillers that can mask rather than treat cause of pain; painkillers can also increase disability payouts and expenses by delaying an employee's return to work.
docs.snippet: Narcotic painkillers, which can mask rather than treat pain, can increase disability payouts and expenses by delaying an employee’s return to work.

docs.lead_paragraph: A growing number of local providers, and even some insurers, are finding ways to improve the American health care system.
docs.abstract: Editorial highlights successful experiments conducted across the United States by hospitals, doctors, employers and health insurers aimed at finding ways to reduce the cost of delivering medical care while maintaining or improving quality; asserts that such experiments emphasize the importance of health care reform, which will give an important boost to the process of lowering costs and improving care.
docs.snippet: A growing number of local providers, and even some insurers, are finding ways to improve the American health care system.

docs.lead_paragraph: With insurance companies asking patients to pay a greater portion of medical bills, America may need to rethink the annual physical exam.
docs.abstract: News analysis; Americans remain committed to yearly physical exams, despite a growing body of evidence that routine tests administered during physical exams are often unnecessary and can, in some cases, be harmful; out of control medical costs may be the required impetus for changing American attitudes toward such tests.
docs.snippet: With insurance companies asking patients to pay a greater portion of medical bills, America may need to rethink the annual physical exam.

docs.lead_paragraph: A sampling of routine screening tests and medical procedures that research has suggested are unnecessary.
docs.snippet: A sampling of routine screening tests and medical procedures that research has suggested are unnecessary.

docs.lead_paragraph: The link between obesity and poverty is close and complicated, as leaders in one city learned when they tried to make high-calorie beverages more expensive.

headline.seo: Richmond, Calif., Seeks to Tax Sweetened Beverages
headline.main: Plan to Tax Soda Gets a Mixed Reception
headline.print_headline: Plan to Tax Soda Gets a Mixed Reception

docs.abstract: Richmond journal; proposed one-cent-per-ounce tax on sugar-sweetened beverages sold in Richmond, Calif, which has double the national poverty rate, is the most visible West Coast municipal challenge yet to soda; tax money would go toward fighting childhood obesity; tax proposal, to appear on the November ballot, is being viewed as a beachhead by a coalition of beverage makers, merchant groups and labor unions who are organizing to defeat it.
docs.snippet: The link between obesity and poverty is close and complicated, as leaders in one city learned when they tried to make high-calorie beverages more expensive.
